themes.name: Separation → Delight
themes.description: From avoidance of the wicked to joy in God's law
themes.comment: The blessed one turns away from the path of the wicked and instead finds delight in the law of the Lord.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as a triple renunciation (consilium → via → cathedra), culminating in the joy of meditating on the Law. For him, the righteous one is defined by inward transformation and desire for God (Enarr. Ps. 1.1–2).

themes.name: Rootedness → Fruitfulness
themes.description: From spiritual planting to lasting vitality and success
themes.comment: The just is like a tree planted by streams, yielding fruit in its season and not withering. This image emphasizes stability, growth, and enduring vitality through divine nourishment.
themes.comment2: Augustine reads the tree as one rooted in grace and Scripture, continually refreshed by Christ, the living water. Its fruit signifies good works in due season, prospering by God’s help (Enarr. Ps. 1.3).

themes.name: Chaff → Separation
themes.description: From unstable wickedness to final divine separation
themes.comment: The wicked cannot stand in judgment or in the assembly of the righteous, for the Lord knows the way of the just while the way of the impious comes to nothing.
themes.comment2: Augustine contrasts the rooted tree of the righteous with the empty lightness of the ungodly. The Lord 'knows' (novit) the way of the just with covenantal intimacy, but the way of the wicked perishes — eternal separation from God (Enarr. Ps. 1.5–6).

themes.name: Rage → Opposition
themes.description: From the turmoil of nations to defiance against the Lord and His Christ
themes.comment: Nations rage in vanity, rulers set themselves against the Lord and His Anointed, revealing the futility of human power against divine kingship.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as the nations plotting against Christ and His Church, yet all human counsels are 'inania'—empty—before the eternal decree of God (Enarr. Ps. 2.1–2).

themes.name: Chains → Laughter
themes.description: From rebellion against divine bonds to God’s derision from heaven
themes.comment: The peoples reject the Lord’s yoke as bondage, but God responds not with fear but with laughter, revealing their revolt as powerless.
themes.comment2: Augustine notes that what the proud see as 'chains' are in fact bonds of love and discipline; God mocks their rebellion as vain pretension (Enarr. Ps. 2.3–4).

themes.name: Wrath → Installation
themes.description: From divine anger to the establishment of the true King on Zion
themes.comment: God answers with wrath, establishing His chosen king upon Zion, His holy mountain.
themes.comment2: Augustine reads Zion as the Church, the place where Christ reigns despite worldly rage; God's anger here manifests as His unshakable justice (Enarr. Ps. 2.5–6).

themes.name: Sonship → Inheritance
themes.description: From divine begetting to the universal rule of the Son
themes.comment: The Lord declares the King to be His begotten Son and grants Him all nations as inheritance and possession.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, 'hodie genui te' refers to the eternal generation of the Son and also to the Resurrection; the inheritance is the Church drawn from all nations (Enarr. Ps. 2.7–8).

themes.name: Rod → Shattering
themes.description: From rule with iron to the breaking of resistance
themes.comment: The Messiah rules with a rod of iron, shattering nations like fragile pottery, yet kings are called to wisdom and instruction.
themes.comment2: Augustine notes the dual sense: the iron rod is both severe judgment and the firm, unbreakable discipline of Christ, which smashes pride but also reforms the humble (Enarr. Ps. 2.9–10).

themes.name: Service → Trust
themes.description: From trembling service to blessed confidence in the Lord
themes.comment: The psalm ends by exhorting rulers to serve with fear, rejoice with trembling, embrace discipline, and find blessing in trust.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as the movement from fear to love: discipline leads to true freedom, and blessedness belongs to all who cling to Christ in humble trust (Enarr. Ps. 2.11–12).

themes.name: Enemies → Doubt
themes.description: From multiplied persecutors to their taunt: no salvation in God
themes.comment: The psalm opens with a cry of affliction: enemies surround and voices of despair rise — 'no salvation in his God.' Augustine sees here the voice of Christ’s body, the Church, mocked in its suffering (Enarr. Ps. 3.1–2).

themes.name: Shield → Hearing
themes.description: From God as protector and glory to the prayer He hears on His holy mountain
themes.comment: Against despair, God is confessed as shield, glory, and lifter of the head. Prayer is not wasted: it ascends and is heard from the holy mountain. Augustine reads this as Christ praying in the Passion, with assurance of the Father’s help (Enarr. Ps. 3.3–4).

themes.name: Sleep → Rising
themes.description: From mortal sleep to resurrection and fearless confidence
themes.comment: The psalmist sleeps and wakes because the Lord sustains him. Augustine sees a mystery of Christ’s death and resurrection, by which the faithful too find courage: they need not fear even a multitude of foes (Enarr. Ps. 3.5–6).

themes.name: Blow → Blessing
themes.description: From God’s strike against enemies to salvation and blessing for His people
themes.comment: God shatters the teeth of sinners, breaking their power to devour. Salvation belongs to the Lord, and His blessing rests on His people. Augustine interprets this as Christ’s victory over sin and death, shared with the Church (Enarr. Ps. 3.7–8).

themes.name: Call → Answer
themes.description: From human invocation to divine enlargement and mercy
themes.comment: God answers with both hearing and enlargement of the heart. The psalmist moves from constriction to freedom by divine mercy.
themes.comment2: Augustine recalls how God 'dilated' his narrow heart during conversion, through Ambrose’s preaching and Monica’s tears (Conf. 9.4.8).

themes.name: Vanity → Truth
themes.description: From clinging to falsehood to beholding divine wonder
themes.comment: The psalmist challenges men who love vanity and lies, redirecting them to the marvel of God’s chosen.
themes.comment2: Augustine recognized his own 'heavy heart' in this appeal: God’s rebuke pierced him as one long ensnared by empty loves (Conf. 9.4.9).

themes.name: Examination → Sacrifice
themes.description: From self-search in silence to offering righteous worship
themes.comment: Nighttime reflection leads to repentance, expressed in offering the sacrifice of righteousness and trusting in the Lord.
themes.comment2: Augustine links this to his garden conversion (shaken in his 'bed' by God’s command) and to Monica’s prayers as true sacrifice that upheld his hope (Conf. 8.12.28–29; 9.4.10–11).

themes.name: Divine Light → Revelation
themes.description: From worldly good to the light of God’s countenance
themes.comment: Earthly blessings pale before the shining of God’s face, which brings true joy.
themes.comment2: Augustine contrasts the fleeting light of philosophy with the sealed light of Scripture — the illumination of God’s face (Conf. 9.4.12).

themes.name: Abundance → Eternal Rest
themes.description: From earthly plenty to the peace of divine rest
themes.comment: Material abundance points beyond itself to the peace found only in God, where the soul rests secure.
themes.comment2: At Ostia, Augustine and Monica tasted this peace — the Eucharistic abundance of 'grain and wine' finding fulfillment in eternal rest (Conf. 9.10.23–26).

themes.name: Speech → Prayer
themes.description: From vocal petition to intimate appeal before God the King
themes.comment: Augustine sees these opening lines as a layering of communication: words (verba), then inward groaning (clamor), then formal petition (oratio). God is not just King but intimate listener (Enarr. Ps. 5.2).

themes.name: Morning → Presence
themes.description: From early prayer to reverent standing before God
themes.comment: The soul rises early to speak and then to watch, anticipating divine presence. Augustine connects this with Christ rising early to pray (Mk 1:35), revealing devotion and attentiveness (Enarr. Ps. 5.4).

themes.name: Evil → Rejection
themes.description: From wicked intentions to divine intolerance
themes.comment: God’s holiness cannot dwell with evil. Augustine sees the dwelling (habitare) as incompatible with impurity; those clinging to iniquity remain outside (Enarr. Ps. 5.5).

themes.name: Blood → Worship
themes.description: From condemnation of the violent to the fear-filled approach to the sanctuary
themes.comment: Contrasting the abominable (abominabitur) with the beloved who enters the temple. Augustine emphasizes that only through mercy (misericordia) does one dare draw near (Enarr. Ps. 5.8).

themes.name: Injustice → Guidance
themes.description: From facing deceitful enemies to seeking righteous direction
themes.comment: Because the enemy lacks truth, the psalmist seeks a path directed by God's justice. Augustine sees this path as Christ, the Way (John 14:6), given to those who reject the empty hearts of the wicked (Enarr. Ps. 5.9–10).

themes.name: Deceit → Judgment
themes.description: From poisonous speech to divine judgment
themes.comment: Their throats are open graves, and their deceit requires divine judgment. Augustine reads this as the corruption of false teachers and the need for God to scatter their vain plots (Enarr. Ps. 5.11–12; Rom 3:13).

themes.name: Hope → Exultation
themes.description: From trusting in God to everlasting joy and communion
themes.comment: Augustine sees this as the fruit of the just soul: exultation and divine indwelling. Hope leads to joy, joy to glory, and glory to divine presence (Enarr. Ps. 5.13–14).

themes.name: Favor → Shield
themes.description: From divine goodwill to crowned protection
themes.comment: God’s favor (voluntas) surrounds the just like a shield. Augustine sees this not only as protection, but glorification—God crowns the soul with His own goodness (Enarr. Ps. 5.15).

themes.name: Wrath → Mercy
themes.description: From divine anger to a plea for healing compassion
themes.comment: The psalmist appeals to God not as a just judge but as a merciful physician. Weakness, both bodily and spiritual, is openly confessed.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets the chastisement ('arguas… corripias') not as condemnation but as medicinal correction, so that frailty may be healed by divine mercy (Enarr. Ps. 6.1–2).

themes.name: Agitation → Rescue
themes.description: From inner turmoil to divine salvation
themes.comment: The psalmist cries out from deep turmoil, pleading for rescue grounded not in merit but in mercy.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, the soul’s turbulence is stilled only by God turning toward it; salvation rests entirely on the mercy of the Lord (Enarr. Ps. 6.3–4).

themes.name: Mortality → Tears
themes.description: From the silence of death to sorrowful intercession
themes.comment: Death is a place of silence where no one confesses God; the psalmist therefore pours out tears in prayer while still alive.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees these tears as compunction, watering the soul like a field, preparing it for renewal by God (Enarr. Ps. 6.5–6).

themes.name: Weariness → Hearing
themes.description: From exhaustion under oppression to God hearing the cry
themes.comment: Weary and worn down among enemies, the psalmist clings to hope because the Lord hears his weeping.
themes.comment2: Augustine emphasizes that God’s hearing ('exaudivit') shows His closeness to the contrite heart, even amid human hostility (Enarr. Ps. 6.7–8).

themes.name: Prayer → Reversal
themes.description: From received prayer to the shame and retreat of enemies
themes.comment: The psalmist’s prayer is not only heard but embraced; enemies are overturned in shame and confusion.
themes.comment2: Augustine highlights the reversal: the psalmist is lifted up ('suscepit'), while enemies are cast down in sudden shame ('erubescant valde velociter')—a figure of the final judgment (Enarr. Ps. 6.9–10).

themes.name: Threat → Refuge
themes.description: From violent pursuit to trusting in divine protection
themes.comment: The psalmist likens persecutors to a lion ready to seize its prey. In response, he entrusts himself to God as the only liberator.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets the lion as the devil or violent adversaries. Safety lies only in the Lord, who receives those fleeing in faith (Enarr. Ps. 7.1–2).

themes.name: Integrity → Collapse
themes.description: If unjust, the psalmist accepts shameful defeat
themes.comment: The psalmist offers himself to God’s judgment: if guilty of betrayal, let him fall empty-handed into enemy hands.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, this is not pride but holy fear: a willingness to be judged shows the integrity of the just. To fall 'inanis' is to lose all fruit of life apart from God (Enarr. Ps. 7.3–4).

themes.name: Capture → Dust
themes.description: From pursuit to utter humiliation
themes.comment: If guilty, let the enemy overtake and trample him, reducing his glory to dust.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees dust as the destiny of the proud soul abandoned to itself: the fall of human glory without God’s defense (Enarr. Ps. 7.5–6).

themes.name: Judgment → Ascent
themes.description: From divine summons to enthronement above all peoples
themes.comment: The Lord rises to judge among assembled nations, taking His seat on high.
themes.comment2: Augustine reads this as Christ exalted after the resurrection, gathering peoples into His Church and judging with justice (Enarr. Ps. 7.7–8).

themes.name: Innocence → Discernment
themes.description: From appeal to justice to God’s searching judgment
themes.comment: The psalmist asks to be judged by his innocence, yet acknowledges God searches even the heart and reins.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, this penetrates deeper than outward acts: God weighs interior motives, revealing true justice (Enarr. Ps. 7.9–10).

themes.name: Righteousness → Warning
themes.description: From God’s help for the upright to warning the impenitent
themes.comment: God is patient and aids the upright, but warns that His forbearance has limits.
themes.comment2: Augustine urges conversion while time remains: God’s patience is meant to lead sinners back, not excuse them forever (Enarr. Ps. 7.11–12).

themes.name: Preparation → Execution
themes.description: From preparation of weapons to fiery judgment
themes.comment: God bends the bow and readies burning arrows, images of judgment.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets these arrows spiritually: divine words pierce sinners, igniting repentance rather than mere destruction (Enarr. Ps. 7.13–14).

themes.name: Conception → Iniquity
themes.description: From conceiving sin to its birth in injustice
themes.comment: The wicked conceive trouble and give birth to iniquity, only to fall into their own pit.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees in this the paradox of the cross: by plotting Christ’s death, the devil trapped himself in the pit he dug (Enarr. Ps. 7.15–16).

themes.name: Retribution → Praise
themes.description: From downfall of the wicked to exaltation of divine justice
themes.comment: The sinner’s violence recoils upon his own head, while the psalmist gives thanks in song.
themes.comment2: Augustine highlights the contrast: the wicked are ensnared in their own works, but the just respond with praise of God’s unchanging righteousness (Enarr. Ps. 7.17–18).

themes.name: Divine Name → Universal Glory
themes.description: From praising God’s name to His majesty exalted above the heavens
themes.comment: The psalmist praises God’s admirable name (‘nomen,’ ‘admirabile’) across the earth, exalting His majesty (‘magnificentia’) above the heavens (‘caelum’).
themes.comment2: Augustine sees ‘nomen’ and ‘admirabile’ as God’s glory revealed universally, with ‘magnificentia’ above ‘caelum’ prefiguring Christ’s ascension (Enarr. Ps. 8.1–2).

themes.name: Weak Praise → Defeat of Enemies
themes.description: From the praise of the weak to the destruction of God’s enemies
themes.comment: God perfects praise (‘laudem’) from infants (‘infans’), confounding the enemy (‘inimicus’) and avenger through their weakness, as He reveals His works (‘opera’) in the heavens.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets ‘infans’ and ‘laudem’ as the humble, including Christ and His Church, silencing the ‘inimicus’ through divine power (Enarr. Ps. 8.3–4).

themes.name: Human Lowliness → Divine Honor
themes.description: From human insignificance to being crowned with glory
themes.comment: The psalmist marvels that God remembers (‘memoro’) man (‘homo’), crowning him (‘corono’) with glory (‘gloria’) and honor, despite his lowliness.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees ‘homo’ as Christ, the Son of Man, whom God ‘memoro’ and ‘corono’ with ‘gloria,’ exalting humanity through Him (Enarr. Ps. 8.5–6).

themes.name: Divine Creation → Human Dominion
themes.description: From God’s works to man’s authority over creation
themes.comment: God establishes (‘constituo’) man over His works (‘opus’), subjecting (‘subicio’) all creation, from sheep to cattle, under his feet (‘pes’).
themes.comment2: Augustine views ‘constituo’ and ‘subicio’ as Christ’s dominion over creation, with ‘opus’ and ‘pes’ symbolizing His authority extended to the Church (Enarr. Ps. 8.7–8).

themes.name: Creation’s Paths → Universal Praise
themes.description: From the creatures of air and sea to renewed praise of God’s name
themes.comment: The birds (‘volucris’) and fish (‘piscis’) traversing creation’s paths lead to renewed praise of God’s admirable name (‘nomen,’ ‘admirabile’) across the earth.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees ‘volucris’ and ‘piscis’ as symbols of the Church’s mission, proclaiming God’s ‘nomen’ and ‘admirabile’ glory universally (Enarr. Ps. 8.9–10).

themes.name: Wonder → Praise
themes.description: From recounting God’s marvelous works to rejoicing in His name
themes.comment: The psalmist begins with wholehearted thanksgiving, rejoicing and singing to the Most High for His wondrous deeds.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees here the Church’s song: the marvels of Christ’s resurrection and the new creation are confessed with joy and psalmody (Enarr. Ps. 9.1–2).

themes.name: Enemy → Judgment
themes.description: From the downfall of enemies to God’s righteous throne
themes.comment: God turns back the enemy, causing them to perish before His face, while He sits enthroned in justice.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as the triumph of Christ over the devil and sin, enthroning God’s judgment as the foundation of the City of God (Enarr. Ps. 9.3–4).

themes.name: Nations → Oblivion
themes.description: From rebuked nations to perishing memory
themes.comment: The nations are rebuked, the wicked perish, their names erased, their cities destroyed, and their memory vanishes in noise.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, this points to earthly kingdoms opposed to God, whose glory fades to nothing, unlike the eternal remembrance of the just (Enarr. Ps. 9.5–6).

themes.name: Eternal Throne → Just Judgment
themes.description: From God’s everlasting throne to equity in judgment
themes.comment: The Lord remains forever, establishing His throne in judgment to govern the earth with righteousness.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees Christ as the eternal Judge, who alone brings true equity — not partial or earthly justice, but eternal righteousness (Enarr. Ps. 9.7–8).

themes.name: Refuge → Trust
themes.description: From God as a refuge for the poor to the trust of those who know His name
themes.comment: The poor find refuge in God, and those who know His name place their trust in Him, confident He will not forsake them.
themes.comment2: Augustine teaches that Christ Himself is the stronghold of the poor, and that true knowledge of God’s name comes through faith in Him (Enarr. Ps. 9.9–10).

themes.name: Zion → Remembrance
themes.description: From psalms in Zion to God remembering the blood of the poor
themes.comment: The psalm calls for song in Zion and the proclamation of God’s works, for He remembers the blood of the oppressed and the cry of the poor.
themes.comment2: Augustine links this to the blood of the martyrs, never forgotten by God, whose cry is heard in His heavenly Zion (Enarr. Ps. 9.11–12).

themes.name: Mortality → Praise
themes.description: From prayer amid death’s gates to praise in Zion’s gates
themes.comment: The psalmist begs God to see his affliction, to raise him from the gates of death, that he may proclaim God’s praise in the gates of Zion.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees here Christ lifting believers from death into the life of the Church, so that the praise of God replaces the silence of the grave (Enarr. Ps. 9.13–14).

themes.name: Trap → Judgment
themes.description: From nations ensnared in their own snares to God’s revealed justice
themes.comment: The nations fall into the pit they made, caught in their hidden traps; the Lord makes Himself known in judgment, ensnaring the sinner by his own works.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as sin turning back on the sinner: the trap of pride becomes the means of downfall, while God’s justice is revealed in this reversal (Enarr. Ps. 9.15–16).

themes.name: Forgetting God → Eternal Loss
themes.description: From sinners descending to hell to hope for the poor
themes.comment: Sinners and nations that forget God are turned into hell, while the poor will not be forgotten and their patience will not perish forever.
themes.comment2: Augustine highlights the contrast: forgetfulness of God leads to eternal loss, but the poor in spirit, patient in faith, are remembered unto life (Enarr. Ps. 9.17–18).

themes.name: Rise Up → Human Limits
themes.description: From God’s rising against human pride to nations learning their mortality
themes.comment: The psalmist begs God to rise so that man does not prevail, and that nations may know they are but human.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees this as the humiliation of pride: nations are taught their weakness under God’s law (Enarr. Ps. 9.1–2B).

themes.name: Distance → Oppression
themes.description: From God’s seeming absence to the poor consumed by the proud
themes.comment: The psalm laments God’s apparent distance as the proud inflame the poor and ensnare them in plots.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as the trial of faith: God seems far, but He never abandons His people (Enarr. Ps. 9.3–4B).

themes.name: Boast → Defilement
themes.description: From the sinner’s self-praise to the corruption of his ways
themes.comment: The sinner boasts in his desires and angers the Lord, refusing to seek God, walking always in defiled paths.
themes.comment2: Augustine contrasts this with the just, who glory not in themselves but in God (Enarr. Ps. 9.5–6B).

themes.name: False Security → Deceit
themes.description: From the wicked’s claim of stability to speech filled with curses and lies
themes.comment: The wicked claim they will not be moved, yet their ways are full of deceit and domination over enemies.
themes.comment2: Augustine says their words betray them: claiming strength, they reveal corruption (Enarr. Ps. 9.7–8B).

themes.name: Boast → Corruption of Tongue
themes.description: From arrogant confidence to a mouth filled with bitterness and fraud
themes.comment: The wicked say in their hearts they will not be moved, but their tongues are full of curses, lies, and bitterness.
themes.comment2: Augustine notes the contrast: the proud heart produces a corrupt tongue, which betrays the inner decay (Enarr. Ps. 9.9–10B).

themes.name: Ambush → Violence
themes.description: From hidden traps to the lion’s den awaiting the poor
themes.comment: The wicked sit in ambush with the wealthy, seeking to kill the innocent, like a lion lurking in his den.
themes.comment2: Augustine applies this to the devil and his agents who hunt the innocent in secret (Enarr. Ps. 9.11–12B).

themes.name: Trap → Denial
themes.description: From snaring the poor to denying God’s sight
themes.comment: The wicked trap the poor, bending low until he falls, while claiming God has forgotten and turned away.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, the wicked think God does not see, but His judgment will expose their false security (Enarr. Ps. 9.13–14B).

themes.name: Exalted Hand → Defender of the Poor
themes.description: From God’s exalted hand to His defense of the orphan
themes.comment: The psalmist calls for God to rise with His hand exalted, not forgetting the poor.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees Christ’s exaltation as the lifting of God’s hand to aid the humble and forgotten (Enarr. Ps. 9.15–16B).

themes.name: Vision → Aid
themes.description: From God’s seeing toil and sorrow to becoming helper of the orphan
themes.comment: The psalmist confesses God sees the labor and pain of His people, entrusting them into His hands and aiding the orphan.
themes.comment2: Augustine emphasizes God’s providence: He sees what men ignore, defending the weakest (Enarr. Ps. 9.17–18B).

themes.name: King Forever → Humble Secured
themes.description: From God’s eternal reign to justice for the poor against human pride
themes.comment: The Lord reigns forever; nations perish from His land while the poor are secured in His Kingdom.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as eschatological hope: the reign of God is eternal, and pride vanishes before His justice (Enarr. Ps. 9.19–20B).

themes.name: Desire → Final Judgment
themes.description: From the prayer of the poor to the end of human self-exaltation
themes.comment: God hears the desire of the poor and judges for the humble, so that man may no longer exalt himself upon the earth.
themes.comment2: Augustine says this is the closing hope: God hears the hidden desires of His saints, securing them against human pride (Enarr. Ps. 9.21–23B).

themes.name: Trust → Flight Questioned
themes.description: From confidence in the Lord to the temptation of fleeing like a bird
themes.comment: The psalmist declares trust in the Lord, rejecting the counsel of fear that urges escape while the wicked prepare their arrows.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets the bird’s flight as vain self-reliance: the just must not flee from trial but trust in God (Enarr. Ps. 10.1–2).

themes.name: Destruction → Divine Throne
themes.description: From the collapse of human works to the Lord enthroned in heaven
themes.comment: When the foundations are destroyed and the just seem powerless, the Lord remains in His holy temple, reigning from heaven.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees this as the stability of God’s reign against human ruin: His temple is unshaken though earthly works collapse (Enarr. Ps. 10.3–4).

themes.name: Divine Gaze → Testing
themes.description: From God’s eyes upon the poor to His testing of the just and wicked
themes.comment: The Lord’s eyes behold the poor, His eyelids test the children of men, examining both the righteous and the wicked.
themes.comment2: Augustine teaches that God’s scrutiny purifies the just but exposes the wicked who hate their own souls through sin (Enarr. Ps. 10.5–6).

themes.name: Judgment → Equity
themes.description: From fire and storm upon sinners to the just Lord who loves righteousness
themes.comment: The wicked drink a cup of fire, sulfur, and storm, while the Lord, who is just, loves righteousness and shows His face in equity.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, the cup of the wicked is eternal punishment, but the vision of God’s face belongs to the just (Enarr. Ps. 10.7–8).

themes.name: Loss of Truth → Deceptive Speech
themes.description: From the vanishing of the faithful to false words and double hearts
themes.comment: The psalmist laments that the holy have failed and truth has diminished, while deceitful lips and divided hearts prevail.
themes.comment2: Augustine reads the 'double heart' as hypocrisy: speaking peace outwardly while concealing malice inwardly (Enarr. Ps. 11.1–2).

themes.name: Prideful Speech → Divine Judgment
themes.description: From boastful tongues to the Lord cutting them off
themes.comment: The Lord will destroy deceitful lips and the arrogant tongue that boasts of self-sufficiency and rejects divine authority.
themes.comment2: For Augustine, pride in one’s own tongue opposes the Word of God; such speech is judged and brought low (Enarr. Ps. 11.3–4).

themes.name: Oppression → Divine Rising
themes.description: From the groaning of the poor to God’s intervention for salvation
themes.comment: God rises because of the suffering of the needy, promising to place them in safety and act faithfully on their behalf.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as Christ rising to redeem the poor in spirit, establishing them securely in salvation (Enarr. Ps. 11.5–6).

themes.name: Pure Words → Preservation
themes.description: From refined speech of the Lord to His eternal protection
themes.comment: The words of the Lord are pure, like silver tested sevenfold, and He preserves His people forever from corruption.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees the 'sevenfold purification' as the fullness of the Spirit, guaranteeing the truth of God’s promises (Enarr. Ps. 11.7–8).

themes.name: Wicked Circling → Human Exaltation
themes.description: From the wicked surrounding to the exaltation of human pride
themes.comment: The psalm ends with the wicked strutting around, while human pride multiplies in defiance of God.
themes.comment2: Augustine contrasts this with the faithful preserved by God: the proud exalt themselves, but the humble are safeguarded (Enarr. Ps. 11.9).

themes.name: Lament in Suffering
themes.description: The psalmist's cry of despair in prolonged suffering
themes.comment: Repeated 'usquequo' (How long?) frames the lament

themes.name: Divine Hiddenness
themes.description: Feeling of God's absence and unanswered prayers
themes.comment: The turned face (avertō faciem) motif

themes.name: Enemy Threat
themes.description: Fear of enemy triumph and gloating
themes.comment: Enemy references escalate from line 3 to 5

themes.name: Petition for Help
themes.description: Direct requests for divine intervention
themes.comment: Imperative verbs: respice (look), exaudi (hear)

themes.name: Trust Transition
themes.description: Shift from lament to confident trust
themes.comment: Pivot to trust (sperāvi) in God's mercy

themes.name: Promise of Praise
themes.description: Vow to worship despite circumstances
themes.comment: Threefold praise verbs: exsultō, canō, psallō

themes.name: Folly of Atheism
themes.description: Condemnation of the fool who denies God's existence
themes.comment: Opening declaration of practical atheism

themes.name: Universal Corruption
themes.description: Description of total human depravity
themes.comment: All humanity is corrupt in deeds

themes.name: Divine Scrutiny
themes.description: God's examination of human understanding
themes.comment: Heavenly perspective on human wisdom

themes.name: Universal Apostasy
themes.description: Reiteration of total human waywardness
themes.comment: Parallel to verse 2 emphasizing universal sin

themes.name: Oppression of the Righteous
themes.description: Warning to those who exploit God's people
themes.comment: Condemnation of social injustice

themes.name: False Fear

themes.name: Plea → Divine Intervention
themes.description: The psalmist cries for God to judge and fight on his behalf against unjust enemies.
themes.comment: Opening plea sets a legal and martial tone—justice is asked not by self-retaliation but divine advocacy.

themes.name: Pursuit → Salvation
themes.description: God is invoked to halt the persecutors and declare His saving presence.
themes.comment: Augustine: God’s voice to the soul—'I am your salvation'—is internal assurance in external conflict (Enarr. Ps. 34.3).

themes.name: Chaff → Angelic Chase
themes.description: The wicked are driven like dust and pursued by God’s angel.
themes.comment: Spiritual warfare intensifies; divine justice is swift and fearful through angelic agency.

themes.name: Trap → Reversal
themes.description: Enemies set traps, but fall into them themselves.
themes.comment: The psalmist invokes poetic justice: their hidden snares become their own downfall.

themes.name: Fear → Joyful Praise
themes.description: The soul rejoices in God’s salvation, and all the bones exult.
themes.comment: Even the bones—symbol of the inner self—praise the incomparable God who saves.

themes.name: Powerlessness → Deliverance
themes.description: God rescues the poor from the powerful and false witnesses.
themes.comment: Social and legal vulnerability becomes the arena for divine vindication.

themes.name: Betrayal → Penitence
themes.description: From soul-wounding injustice to humble intercession through fasting, sackcloth and prayer
themes.comment: Augustine reads this transition as a portrait of Christ: betrayed by those He loved, He responds not with wrath but with suffering charity. The psalmist puts on sackcloth ('cilicium'), fasts ('ieiunium'), and turns his prayer inward ('sinus') — a gesture of transformation through humility (Enarr. Ps. 34.13–14; Phil 2:7).

themes.name: Sackcloth → Bosom
themes.description: From outward humility and fasting to inward, returning prayer
themes.comment: Augustine reads 'cilicium' as the flesh Christ assumed in humility. The psalmist fasts ('jejunium') and his prayer returns 'into his bosom' ('sinus') — a gesture of interior transformation and divine charity. It prefigures Christ’s suffering intercession for others (Enarr. Ps. 34.13–14; Phil 2:7).
themes.comment2: The psalmist fasted and mourned for others as for a brother, clothed in sackcloth (cilicium). Yet they returned his love with scorn. Augustine sees this as Christ-like charity — unrequited and redemptive. The turning of prayer into the bosom ('sinus') reflects inward forgiveness and self-offering (Enarr. Ps. 34.13–14; Phil 2:7).

themes.name: Friendship → Scourging
themes.description: From deep empathy and mourning to attack and mockery.
themes.comment: Augustine: 'They gathered against me unrepentant'—a contrast between interior love and exterior malice (Enarr. Ps. 34.15).

themes.name: Scorn → Supplication
themes.description: From violent ridicule and gnashing hatred to a desperate plea for rescue
themes.comment: Augustine sees the subsannation and frendentes dentes as the height of scorn toward Christ or the righteous soul. In response, the psalmist turns fully to God—'When will You look?'—begging rescue from a lion's mouth. 'Unicam meam' reflects the singular soul's worth, or even Christ’s unique life (Enarr. Ps. 34.17–18).

themes.name: Politeness → Treachery
themes.description: From outward gestures of peace to hidden malice and deceit
themes.comment: Augustine notes the enemy’s 'peaceful speech' hides an 'earth-born rage' (iracundia terrae), a hypocrisy of false friendship. The winking eye (annuunt oculis) signals betrayal, like Judas with a kiss. This duplicity wounds more than open enemies (Enarr. Ps. 34.19–20).

themes.name: Peace → Mockery
themes.description: From false words of peace to open gloating over suffering
themes.comment: Augustine sees in these verses the wicked smiling with their lips while raging in their hearts. 'Euge, euge' is their cry of triumph, mocking the just as they fall. This mirrors the Passion: Christ, betrayed by feigned friendship, faced open derision (Enarr. Ps. 34.21–22; Luke 22:48).

themes.name: Injustice → Divine Advocacy
themes.description: From unjust persecution to appeal for God’s righteous intervention
themes.comment: Augustine reads this as the soul calling upon God not for vengeance but for justice rooted in divine truth. The psalmist entrusts his cause ('causam meam') to God's tribunal, resisting the pride of self-defense (Enarr. Ps. 34.23–24).

themes.name: Boasting → Shame
themes.description: From hidden gloating over downfall to public shame and reversal
themes.comment: Augustine interprets the enemy’s gloating ('devoravimus eum') as pride in persecuting the righteous—yet this triumph is hollow. The psalmist calls for their undoing: shame and confusion will clothe those who exalted themselves (Enarr. Ps. 34.25–26).

themes.name: Persecution → Praise
themes.description: From suffering among enemies to shared joy among the just
themes.comment: Augustine sees a final turn: not only is the soul rescued, but the just are called into praise. Peace returns through God’s justice, and the psalmist’s voice—once silenced by sorrow—now proclaims truth daily (Enarr. Ps. 34.27–28).

themes.name: Praise → All Day Long
themes.description: From voiceless affliction to all-day meditation on God's justice
themes.comment: Augustine sees 'tota die' as the seal of deliverance: the tongue, once silenced by enemies, now rejoices without interruption. Meditation becomes praise; suffering gives way to full-day worship (Enarr. Ps. 34.29).

themes.name: Greatness → Holy City
themes.description: From God’s greatness to His dwelling on Zion, the joy of the whole earth
themes.comment: The psalm begins with praise of the Lord’s greatness, made visible in Mount Zion, the city of the great King. Augustine interprets Zion as the Church, exalted above the world and a sign of universal joy (Enarr. Ps. 47.1–2).

themes.name: God Present → Nations Shaken
themes.description: From God’s presence in His city to the trembling of gathered kings
themes.comment: God is known within His holy dwellings, defending His city. Earthly rulers, gathering in pride, are confounded before Him, for no power endures against His protection (Enarr. Ps. 47.3–4).

themes.name: Terror → Travail
themes.description: From astonishment of kings to the image of labor pains
themes.comment: The nations behold and are seized with fear, like women in travail. Augustine reads this as the world’s powers convulsed when confronted with Christ’s resurrection and the rise of His Church (Enarr. Ps. 47.5–6).

themes.name: Storm → Foundation
themes.description: From the breaking of ships to the eternal stability of God’s city
themes.comment: As ships are shattered by a mighty wind, so earthly strength collapses before God. Yet Zion stands firm, founded forever — the eternal dwelling of the Lord (Enarr. Ps. 47.7–8).

themes.name: Mercy → Praise
themes.description: From receiving God’s mercy in the temple to worldwide proclamation of His justice
themes.comment: In the midst of the temple the faithful receive God’s mercy. His name and praise extend to the ends of the earth, His right hand full of justice — Christ’s redeeming power made manifest (Enarr. Ps. 47.9–10).

themes.name: Joy → Witness
themes.description: From Zion’s gladness to the charge to tell future generations
themes.comment: Zion rejoices in God’s judgments, and her towers are to be recounted as testimony. Augustine sees the Church’s witness as a lasting proclamation to all generations (Enarr. Ps. 47.11–12).

themes.name: Strength → Eternal Shepherd
themes.description: From reflecting on Zion’s strength to God’s everlasting reign
themes.comment: The faithful are called to ponder Zion’s strength, for it proclaims God’s eternal reign. Augustine identifies this ruler as Christ, the shepherd who guides His people forever (Enarr. Ps. 47.13–14).

themes.name: Penitence
themes.description: Recognition and contrition for sin
themes.comment: David's confession begins with a plea for mercy (*misereor*) and acknowledges sin (*peccatum*, *iniquitas*)

themes.name: Divine Mercy
themes.description: Appeals to God's compassionate nature
themes.comment: Mercy is rooted in God's nature (*misericordia*) and enacted through cleansing (*lava*, *deleo*)

themes.name: Purification
themes.description: Ritual and spiritual cleansing
themes.comment: Hyssop symbolizes purification; washing metaphors (*lavabis*) transcend ritual

themes.name: Heart Transformation
themes.description: Request for inner renewal
themes.comment: A new heart (*cor mundum*) and spirit (*spiritum rectum*) are God's work

themes.name: True Sacrifice
themes.description: Contrition over ritual offerings
themes.comment: God rejects empty sacrifices (*holocaustis*) but accepts a broken spirit (*spiritus contribulatus*)

themes.name: Restoration
themes.description: Renewal of joy and mission
themes.comment: Forgiveness restores joy (*laetitiam*) and enables teaching (*docebo*)

themes.name: Augustine: True Penance
themes.description: Self-knowledge and humility in confession
themes.comment: Augustine emphasizes truth (*veritatem*) and humility (*humiliata*) as prerequisites for mercy

themes.name: Augustine: Hyssop of Humility
themes.description: Purification through lowliness
themes.comment: Hyssop cleanses because it signifies humility (*ossa humiliata*)

themes.name: Augustine: Spiritual Sacrifice
themes.description: Contrite heart as true worship
themes.comment: Rejects ritual (*holocaustis*) for inward sacrifice (*spiritus contribulatus*)

themes.name: Augustine: City of God
themes.description: Jerusalem as the redeemed community
themes.comment: The rebuilding of Jerusalem (line 19) and altar offerings (line 20) prefigure the Church (cf. *City of God*, XVII)

themes.name: Speech → Iniquity
themes.description: Contrast between professed justice and practiced wickedness
themes.comment: Augustine: 'Loquimini justitiam' vs 'in corde iniquitates' shows tongue-heart divide (Enarrationes 56.2)

themes.name: Womb → Error
themes.description: Sin's origin from conception
themes.comment: Augustine: 'Ab utero' confirms original sin's transmission (De Peccatorum Meritis I.9)

themes.name: Ears → Obstinacy
themes.description: Willful rejection of truth
themes.comment: Augustine: Deaf adder symbolizes unrepentant soul (Sermon 76.5)

themes.name: Teeth → Judgment
themes.description: Divine dismantling of evil's instruments
themes.comment: Augustine: Crushed teeth signify broken power to harm (Enarrationes 56.8)

themes.name: Wax → Purification
themes.description: Transience of wickedness before divine fire
themes.comment: Augustine: Melting wax represents sinners before God's light (Confessions XIII.15)

themes.name: Blood → Vindication
themes.description: Righteous celebration of divine justice
themes.comment: Augustine: 'Lavabit in sanguine' symbolizes participation in Christ's victory (City of God XVII.7)

themes.name: Augustine: Cor Duplex
themes.description: Heart's division between truth and iniquity
themes.comment: Tension between 'loquimini justitiam' and 'in corde iniquitates' (De Trinitate XIV.17)

themes.name: Augustine: Serpens Aures
themes.description: Spiritual deafness as primal sin
themes.comment: Echo of Adam's willful disobedience (De Genesi contra Manichaeos II.15)

themes.name: Augustine: Ignis Illustratio
themes.description: Fire as divine truth exposing evil
themes.comment: Sinners' impermanence revealed by God's light (Enarrationes 56.12)

themes.name: Soul's Thirst
themes.description: Intense spiritual longing for God's presence.
themes.comment: Desert imagery emphasizing spiritual thirst

themes.name: Divine Refuge
themes.description: God as protector and sustainer.
themes.comment: Wing and hand imagery for protection

themes.name: Sacred Praise

themes.comment: Praise from dawn to dark

themes.name: Divine Justice

themes.name: Royal Vindication

themes.name: Divine Protection

themes.comment: God's defense against collective evil.

themes.name: Enemy Weapons

themes.name: Righteous Vindication

themes.name: Eschatological Joy

themes.comment: Creation personified in celebration

themes.name: Divine Face Metaphor
themes.description: God's countenance shining upon His people
themes.comment: Illuminet vultum suum super nos - classic biblical metaphor for divine favor

themes.name: Agricultural Blessings
themes.description: Earth's fruitfulness as divine blessing
themes.comment: Terra dedit fructum suum - personification of earth yielding its produce

themes.name: Universal Worship
themes.description: All nations called to praise God
themes.comment: Repeated calls for global confession and praise

themes.name: Divine Guidance
themes.description: God's direction of nations and individuals
themes.comment: Judging peoples with equity and guiding nations

themes.name: Cosmic Benediction
themes.description: Global scope of God's blessing
themes.comment: Omnes fines terrae - hyperbolic expression of universal reverence

themes.name: Joyful Judgment
themes.description: Righteous rule producing celebration
themes.comment: Paradox of nations rejoicing under divine judgment

themes.name: Liturgical Blessing
themes.description: Priestly benediction structure
themes.comment: Mirrors Aaronic blessing (Numbers 6:24-26)

themes.name: Ecological Obedience
themes.description: Earth's response to divine will
themes.comment: Personification of creation fulfilling its purpose

themes.name: Known → Dwelt
themes.description: God’s identity, once proclaimed among Judah, becomes presence—He now dwells among His people in Zion.
themes.comment: Augustine: God is not merely known, but has made a peaceful home among His people. Recognition matures into relationship (Enarr. Ps. 75.1).
themes.comment2: The psalm’s journey begins with the movement from public knowledge to relational presence—God is not just confessed, but dwelling.

themes.name: War → Wonder
themes.description: Weapons are shattered and war ceases; God's light dawns from the eternal hills.
themes.comment: Augustine: The hills ‘aeterni’ represent divine peace. The God who shatters weapons offers not retaliation but revelation (Enarr. Ps. 75.3–4).
themes.comment2: This is the psalm’s second step: violence is answered by light, fear by awe—war gives way to wonder.

themes.name: Pride → Powerlessness
themes.description: The arrogant are reduced to sleep and silence by divine rebuke.
themes.comment: Augustine: Sleep here is judgment, not rest. The self-reliant fall powerless at God's rebuke (Enarr. Ps. 75.5–6).
themes.comment2: A humbling phase in the psalm's movement—earthly pride is unseated to prepare for true reverence.

themes.name: Wrath → Silence
themes.description: God's judgment silences even the earth—wrath gives way to sacred stillness.
themes.comment: Augustine: Divine wrath makes the whole earth tremble and then still—‘quievit terra’ signals reverence and awe (Enarr. Ps. 75.7–8).
themes.comment2: This transition shifts from divine anger to cosmic stillness—wrath yields to quiet readiness for worship.

themes.name: Judgment → Festival
themes.description: God rises to save the meek, and human thoughts are transformed into festal worship.
themes.comment: Augustine: The ‘reliquiae cogitationis’ are those thoughts that remain after judgment—redeemed and turned to praise (Enarr. Ps. 75.10).
themes.comment2: The psalm’s arc completes here: from judgment to joy. The final word is celebration—worship from those God has saved.

themes.name: Day/Night Cry → Unanswered Prayer
themes.description: Persistent prayer meets divine silence
themes.comment: Augustine reads the day/night contrast as the psalmist's unceasing prayer (Rom 12:12), yet God's ear seems un-inclined. This mirrors Christ's cry on the cross—the righteous may endure seasons where heaven seems silent, yet still call faithfully.

themes.name: Life → Brink of Sheol
themes.description: The soul's descent into death's dominion
themes.comment: Augustine allegorizes this as the soul's despair when grace feels absent. 'Counted among those who go down' reflects our solidarity with fallen humanity. The paradox of 'free among the dead' suggests the righteous suffer like all mortals, yet retain hope's freedom even in darkness.

themes.name: Divine Memory → Divine Rejection
themes.description: From being forgotten to being actively repelled
themes.comment: Augustine sees here the terror of reprobation—when God's hand no longer sustains but pushes away. The 'wounded sleeping in tombs' represent souls dead in sin, unaware of their peril until divine judgment awakens them.

themes.name: Human Companionship → Utter Isolation
themes.description: From community to abhorred outcast
themes.comment: Augustine compares this to Christ's abandonment by disciples. The 'waves' are adversities permitted by God; the 'abomination' reflects how the righteous become offensive to the worldly when suffering reveals their fragility.

themes.name: Vision → Blindness
themes.description: Eyes fail as poverty overwhelms
themes.comment: Augustine reads this as spiritual blindness—when distress dims the soul's vision of God. The 'spread hands' gesture mirrors Christ on the cross, showing prayer persists even when strength fails.

themes.name: Miracles → Grave's Silence
themes.description: God's wonders seem absent in death's realm
themes.comment: Augustine notes these rhetorical questions find their answer in Christ's resurrection. The 'physicians' (law/works) cannot raise the dead—only grace can. The grave's silence precedes Easter's dawn.

themes.name: Mercy/Truth → Land of Oblivion
themes.description: Divine attributes seem negated by death's oblivion
themes.comment: Augustine sees this as the soul's darkest trial—when God's promises seem void amid suffering. Yet this very cry becomes, in Christ, the 'Eloi' moment that precedes resurrection (Mk 15:34).

themes.name: Rejection → Relentless Prayer
themes.description: Divine hiddenness met with dogged supplication
themes.comment: Augustine observes how the psalmist, like Job, argues with God rather than disengages. 'Morning prayer' signifies hope persisting through night—the discipline of seeking God's face even when He seems to avert it.

themes.name: Youthful Labor → Aged Desolation
themes.description: A life of suffering culminates in final turmoil
themes.comment: Augustine reads this as the soul's lifelong battle with concupiscence—the 'exaltation' of pride followed by crushing humiliations. The 'terrors' are ultimately medicinal, driving us to grace.

themes.name: Solitude → Encircling Flood
themes.description: Isolation gives way to overwhelming assault
themes.comment: Augustine interprets the encircling waters as both external persecutions and internal temptations. Yet this flood, like Noah's, carries the sufferer to God's new creation—the very waves that seem to destroy become the path to salvation.

themes.name: Time → Eternity
themes.description: From generational life to God's timeless refuge
themes.comment: Augustine emphasizes that God's eternity stands outside all generations. While humans come and go, God remains constant: 'a saeculo et usque in saeculum tu es'. He sees this as a comfort and a warning — our only lasting refuge is found outside time, in God Himself.

themes.name: Pride → Repentance
themes.description: Human fall reversed through conversion
themes.comment: When God says 'Convertimini, filii hominum,' Augustine hears the voice of mercy calling fallen humanity home. The 'return' is not geographical but spiritual — turning from pride to humility. He links this to Adam's exile and the lifelong journey of conversion for every soul.

themes.name: Years → Nothingness
themes.description: A thousand years dissolve in divine light
themes.comment: To Augustine, 'mille anni... tamquam dies hesterna' illustrates God's eternity more than human brevity. The contrast reveals how God sees history in a single glance. Augustine says human pride in longevity is shattered by this — for to God, all time is as nothing unless filled with love.

themes.name: Flourishing → Fading
themes.description: Life’s morning beauty withers by evening
themes.comment: Augustine compares the morning grass to the person who flourishes outwardly — perhaps in beauty or power — but has no deep root in charity. Like Christ’s parable of the sower, they spring up quickly and wither when trial comes. Only love makes the soul endure the heat of the day.

themes.name: Wrath → Illumination
themes.description: Divine anger met by the light of His face
themes.comment: Augustine says God's wrath isn't like human passion, but His just judgment. Yet even as He exposes iniquity, His 'illumination' is healing. He calls the face of God 'that which enlightens and reforms the heart' — wrath convicts, but the light restores.

themes.name: Span → Spiderweb
themes.description: Human years dissolve into fragile thought
themes.comment: Life, Augustine says, is like a spider’s web: beautiful yet easily destroyed. 'Meditabuntur' means our years are only murmurs, barely substantial. Even the strong (those who reach eighty) live in toil and sorrow — unless grace transforms their labor.

themes.name: Severity → Instruction
themes.description: From divine wrath to heart-wisdom
themes.comment: ‘Quis novit potestatem irae tuae?’ Augustine asks with awe. God’s wrath is real, but it brings correction. Through fear — not terror, but reverent awe — the soul becomes wise. The paradox of divine gentleness and wrath is resolved in discipline that leads to understanding.

themes.name: Marking → Mercy
themes.description: From divine rebuke to personal pleading
themes.comment: Augustine sees God’s right hand as both powerful and personal. 'Nota fac' implies a divine imprint — a sign of election and instruction. The plea 'Convertere, Domine, usquequo?' is both lament and hope. Augustine says the soul longs for a merciful God who still owns His servants.

themes.name: Affliction → Joy
themes.description: Suffering transfigured into satisfaction
themes.comment: Augustine reflects on how joy does not erase past suffering, but redeems it. 'Repleti sumus mane misericordia tua' suggests a resurrection morning — when divine light returns. The works of our hands, he says, matter only when directed by God, and joy follows obedience through trials.

themes.name: Divine Shelter → Heavenly Protection
themes.description: From dwelling in God’s help to abiding under His protection
themes.comment: The psalm opens with confidence: to dwell in God’s help is to rest under His protection, safe from every danger.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as the faithful resting in Christ, who is Himself the refuge and heavenly shelter (Enarr. Ps. 90.1–2).

themes.name: Trust in God → Divine Deliverance
themes.description: From confessing God as refuge to deliverance from snares
themes.comment: The psalmist proclaims God as refuge and savior, trusting in His power to deliver from hidden traps and threats.
themes.comment2: Augustine sees ‘susceptor’ and ‘refugium’ fulfilled in Christ, who liberates from spiritual snares and false voices (Enarr. Ps. 90.3–4).

themes.name: Divine Covering → Fearless Trust
themes.description: From God’s sheltering wings to fearless confidence
themes.comment: God’s protective wings symbolize His nearness; His truth is a shield, removing fear of unseen terrors.
themes.comment2: Augustine reads the wings as God’s mercy and the shield as Christ’s truth, freeing the Church from fear (Enarr. Ps. 90.5–6).

themes.name: Destruction of Enemies → Safety of the Faithful
themes.description: From the downfall of thousands to the preservation of the just
themes.comment: Though multitudes fall in judgment, the faithful are preserved and see the punishment of the wicked.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets the thousands as the fallen powers of the enemy, while the faithful safely watch God’s judgment (Enarr. Ps. 90.7–8).

themes.name: Hope in God → Divine Refuge
themes.description: From personal trust to God’s protection of the household
themes.comment: Hope in God transforms Him into a dwelling-place, keeping evil far from one’s home.
themes.comment2: Augustine links this to Christ as the true dwelling: in Him, the faithful are kept from ultimate harm (Enarr. Ps. 90.9–10).

themes.name: Angelic Guardians → Safe Journey
themes.description: From angelic command to protection on life’s path
themes.comment: God sends His angels to guard the faithful, preventing stumbling along the way.
themes.comment2: Augustine applies this to the apostolic preachers — angels in function — who protect believers from stumbling in faith (Enarr. Ps. 90.11–12).

themes.name: Triumph over Evil → Victory over Serpents
themes.description: From treading on serpents to conquering all hostile beasts
themes.comment: The imagery of trampling lions and serpents depicts victory over deadly and violent enemies.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets aspis, basilisk, and lion as figures of Satan and his powers, defeated in Christ by the faithful’s perseverance (Enarr. Ps. 90.13–14).

themes.name: Trustful Cry → Divine Salvation
themes.description: From crying to God in trust to His saving response
themes.comment: The psalm closes with the faithful crying out in trust, and God’s promise of salvation, long life, and glory.
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets this as the Church’s prayer fulfilled in Christ: through His exaltation comes salvation and eternal glory (Enarr. Ps. 90.15–16).

themes.name: Divine Praise
themes.description: Celebration of God's character through worship
themes.comment: Opens with call to praise (*confiteor*) and musical worship (*psallo*), emphasizing joy (*exsultabo*)

themes.name: Musical Worship
themes.description: Instruments as vehicles for devotion
themes.comment: Specific instruments (*cithara*) reflect temple worship practices

themes.name: Divine Wisdom
themes.description: Contrast between God's knowledge and human limitation
themes.comment: God's deep (*profundae*) thoughts contrast with foolishness (*stultus*)

themes.name: Righteous Flourishing
themes.description: Metaphors of growth and stability
themes.comment: Botanical imagery (*cedrus Libani*) symbolizes enduring vitality

themes.name: Divine Justice
themes.description: Temporal judgment and eternal sovereignty
themes.comment: Wicked perish (*pereo*) while God's justice (*rectus*) endures

themes.name: Temporal vs Eternal
themes.description: Contrast between transient evil and enduring God
themes.comment: Sinners like grass (*fenum*) vs God's eternity (*in aeternum*)

themes.name: Temple Imagery
themes.description: Sacred space as locus of blessing
themes.comment: Planted (*plantati*) in God's courts (*atriis*)

themes.name: Augustine: True Worship
themes.description: Inner disposition over ritual form
themes.comment: Augustine connects praise (*confiteor*) with moral uprightness (*rectus*)

themes.name: Augustine: Two Destinies
themes.description: Eschatological contrast of outcomes
themes.comment: Wicked scatter (*dispergentur*) while righteous flourish (*florebunt*)

themes.name: Augustine: Spiritual Longevity
themes.description: Enduring grace in old age
themes.comment: Horn (*cornu*) as symbol of strength in later years (*senecta uberi*)

themes.name: Exultation → Thanksgiving
themes.description: From joyful shouting to approaching God with confession and psalms
themes.comment: The psalm begins with a call to joyful worship, urging the faithful to approach God with psalms and thanksgiving. Augustine sees this as the Church’s daily summons to open the heart in praise (Enarr. Ps. 94.1–2).
themes.comment2: For Augustine, this exultant song is the 'new song' of the New Covenant in Christ, who is Himself our salvation. The jubilus — a cry beyond words — expresses the soul’s stretching toward eternity (Enarr. Ps. 94.1).

themes.name: Greatness → Dominion
themes.description: From the greatness of God to His sovereignty over creation’s boundaries
themes.comment: The Lord is proclaimed as king above all gods, whose hands hold both the earth’s limits and the heights of the mountains. Augustine underlines that no realm lies outside His dominion (Enarr. Ps. 94.3–4).
themes.comment2: Augustine links this sovereignty to Christ the King, to whom the Father has given 'all things in His hand' (John 3:35). The mountains symbolize the proud, and the depths the humble — yet all are under Christ’s rule.

themes.name: Sea → Adoration
themes.description: From God as maker of sea and land to worship before Him who made us
themes.comment: The sea and the dry land are His creation, and so the faithful are summoned to kneel before their Maker. Augustine contrasts this humility with the pride of those who refuse to bow (Enarr. Ps. 94.5–6).
themes.comment2: Augustine recalls Christ calming the sea (Mark 4:39): He who made the waters also rules their storms. Thus, adoration of the Creator is fulfilled in bowing to Christ, through whom all was made (John 1:3).

themes.name: People → Voice
themes.description: From belonging to God’s flock to hearing His voice today
themes.comment: God’s people are the sheep of His hand, called to listen today if they hear His voice. Augustine stresses the urgency of 'hodie'—today is the time of obedience and conversion (Enarr. Ps. 94.7–8).
themes.comment2: Christ is the Shepherd, and we the sheep of His pasture (John 10:14). Augustine emphasizes that 'today' points to the present moment of grace in Christ — the acceptable time of salvation (2 Cor 6:2).

themes.name: Testing → Rebellion
themes.description: From the desert trial to the provocation of a hardened heart
themes.comment: The desert generation tested and provoked the Lord, though they saw His works. Augustine recalls this as a warning for the Church, lest we repeat their unbelief (Enarr. Ps. 94.9–10).
themes.comment2: Augustine interprets the desert testing as prefiguring Christ, the Rock struck to give living water (1 Cor 10:4). The provocation warns us not to harden our hearts against the grace poured out in Him.

themes.name: Error → Exclusion
themes.description: From wandering hearts to the oath of exclusion from God’s rest
themes.comment: For forty years the Lord bore with a wayward people, declaring they would not enter His rest. Augustine interprets this as the eternal rest of God, entered only by faith and obedience (Enarr. Ps. 94.11).
themes.comment2: Augustine sees 'requies' as Christ Himself, our Sabbath rest (Matt 11:28–29). Those hardened in unbelief cannot enter. Thus the psalm anticipates the Church’s hope: eternal rest in Christ’s kingdom.

themes.name: Exodus → Sanctification
themes.description: From departure out of Egypt to being made holy and empowered by God.
themes.comment: The redemptive journey begins with God's deliverance and culminates in Israel becoming His sanctified people.

themes.name: Sea → Leaping Hills
themes.description: From receding waters to mountains dancing with life
themes.comment: Augustine sees grace moving nature: the waters flee, and the hills leap. Rams represent the strong in faith; lambs, the humble. All creation responds to God’s presence in a joyful transformation (Enarr. Ps. 113.4–6).

themes.name: Terror → Submission
themes.description: From rhetorical awe to acknowledgment of nature’s obedience to God.
themes.comment: Questions provoke reflection on why nature trembled—pointing to God as the true cause of submission.

themes.name: Rock → Water
themes.description: From immovable rock to life-giving waters by the power of Christ
themes.comment: Augustine sees standing water and springing wells. Petra and rupes (flint stone) as Christ, from whom living waters flow. The stagnum (pool) and fontes (springs) represent the grace Christ bestows — as fulfilled in John 7:37–38. The transformation of rock into water is the mystery of Christ’s provision (Enarr. Ps. 113.8; 1 Cor 10:4; Jn 7:37).

themes.name: Glory → Defense
themes.description: From divine glorification to defense of God's reputation among the nations.
themes.comment: Glory is due to God's name alone; His mercy and truth vindicate Him before skeptical nations.

themes.name: Creator → Contrast
themes.description: From God's sovereignty in heaven to the lifelessness of idols on earth.
themes.comment: God acts freely in heaven while idols, made by human hands, are mute and impotent.

themes.name: Senses → Absence
themes.description: From visible senses in idols to complete spiritual absence.
themes.comment: Though shaped with sensory organs, idols lack all life and power—mockery of divine perception.

themes.name: Impotence → Imitation
themes.description: From motionless idols to the spiritual deadness of their makers.
themes.comment: The lifelessness of idols reflects back on those who trust them: a descent into spiritual sterility.

themes.name: Hope → Help
themes.description: From trusting in God to receiving His aid and protection.
themes.comment: The pattern of trust followed by divine response solidifies the covenantal relationship.

themes.name: Remembrance → Blessing
themes.description: From God’s memory of His people to His active blessing upon all.
themes.comment: God’s memory is not passive—it initiates blessing across generations and social ranks.

themes.name: Expansion → Praise
themes.description: From increase in family and land to praise among the living.
themes.comment: The psalm closes in a crescendo of praise—from earthly blessings to the eternal praise of the living.
